events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker, who in a neutral and informative tone, introduces the concept of a solenoid, describing it as "nothing more than a single loop of wire" placed next to other loops. He explains the ideal solenoid as having loops of wire carrying current with planes oriented parallel to each other. The speech concludes with him summarizing his definition by saying, "so that's the ideal solenoid."

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker with a clear, informative tone, explaining how to make a solenoid by curling a long piece of wire around a cylinder, creating turns of copper wire, and emphasizing the importance of carefully choosing the number of turns. He notes that a solenoid is essentially a coil of tightly wound wire.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with an illustration of a solenoid, a coil of wire, with magnetic field lines emanating from it. The text "A 'solenoid' is a wire that has been wound many times into loops." is displayed at the bottom, explaining the concept of a solenoid. The scene transitions to a diagram showing the magnetic field lines around a solenoid, with a red box containing the equation "B = μ₀nI" on the right side, indicating the formula for the magnetic field inside a solenoid. The video then shows a more detailed diagram of the magnetic field lines around a solenoid, with the equation "B = μ₀nI" in a red box on the right side, and a red line indicating the direction of the magnetic field. The video continues to display the same diagram with the equation "B = μ₀nI" in a red box on the right side, and a red line indicating the direction of the magnetic field. The video concludes with the same diagram, but the equation in the red box changes to "B = μ₀nI / (2(R + x))", indicating a variation in the magnetic field strength with distance from the solenoid. Throughout the video, the focus is on the solenoid and its magnetic field, with no people or other objects present.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker begins in a neutral, instructional tone, discussing electricity and solenoids. He introduces the concept of current flowing through a single wire loop, explaining how it creates a magnetic field similar to a bar magnet's dipole field and why magnetic monopoles aren't observed in nature, attributing this to the motion of electric current. The speaker finishes by saying that magnetic fields require generation of something complicated, which looks like a dipole field.

events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker with a formal tone begins by posing a hypothetical scenario, then moves on to describing a visual example involving loops of wire and magnetic fields. events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker explaining that one can create a solenoid by taking "wire," winding it around a non-conducting form like plastic or glass to create "many tightly spaced loops of wire." He explains that when current runs through the wire, it creates a magnetic field and that "in the center, they all add up." He uses the example of a magnetic resonance imaging device and states, "This is the principle for instance of how one creates a very strong uniform magnetic field." Then, the speaker notes that he has shown a computer map of the magnetic field inside an MRI solenoid. The speech is instructional.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a graphical representation of a solenoid, a coil of wire, with a color gradient indicating the intensity of the magnetic field inside it. The colors range from green to red, with red representing the highest intensity. The solenoid is shown with seven turns, and the magnetic field lines are depicted as concentric circles within the coil. The background is a gradient of green, and there is a scale on the right side indicating the magnetic field strength in Tesla (T). The text on the image reads, "A seven-turn (N=7) solenoid. See how the magnetic field inside is becoming EXTREMELY uniform? In fact, the equation for a magnetic field inside an ideal solenoid is just: B_inside solenoid = (μ₀ N I) / L = n μ₀ I B_inside solenoid = μ₀ n I," explaining the uniformity of the magnetic field inside the solenoid and providing the relevant equation. The video then transitions to a black and white diagram of the same solenoid, with the magnetic field lines shown as arrows pointing outward from the coil. The text remains the same, emphasizing the uniformity of the magnetic field inside the solenoid and providing the equation for calculating it. The video maintains this black and white diagram throughout the remaining frames, with no changes in the visual representation or text.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker begins, adopting an explanatory tone, describing a magnetic field inside of a solenoid. He mentions that he is not going to "derive this for you" but will instead "show it to you". He continues to explain the permeability of free space, the "number of turns of wire", and how each loop creates its own magnetic field. The speaker concludes by describing how one can control the magnetic field.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a static image of a seven-turn solenoid with magnetic field lines illustrated around it. The diagram shows the solenoid with seven coils, and the magnetic field lines are depicted as arrows pointing from one end of the solenoid to the other, indicating the direction of the magnetic field. The text accompanying the image explains that the magnetic field inside the solenoid is extremely uniform and provides the equation for the magnetic field inside an ideal solenoid: B_inside_solenoid = (μ₀N/L)I, where μ₀ is the permeability of free space, N is the number of turns, L is the length of the solenoid, and I is the current flowing through the solenoid. The equation is further simplified to B_inside_solenoid = μ₀nI, where n is the number of turns per unit length. The background is plain white, and the image is black and white, emphasizing the educational content. There are no people, objects, or environmental details beyond the diagram and text. The video maintains this static image throughout, with no visual changes or transitions between frames.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the properties of a "tightly wound solenoid" and how its dimensions affect the "strong magnetic field" inside. He explains that the magnetic field can be weakened by increasing its length or reducing the number of wire turns. The speaker maintains a measured, explanatory tone throughout.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the manufacturing of a solenoid. He explains how 'n over l' is rewritten as a smaller 'n' which is referred to as "the number density." He provides an example of buying a solenoid, stating, "You don't buy it and ask for a solenoid that's exactly one meter long with so many turns." He also mentions that with number density and length, one can cut the solenoid to get a certain number of turns. The tone is educational and explanatory.
